webTitle: Yes or no, Scots will 'just get on with it', says Scotland's first billionaire

fields.standfirst: Sir Tom Hunter, who is backing fund for start-ups in Scotland, refuses to publicly take sides in independence debate
fields.body:
Scottish business will "just get on with it" whatever its people decide on independence, according to Ayrshire-born tycoon Sir Tom Hunter who is backing a fund to support entrepreneurial start-ups.

Hunter is contributing £700,000 to a £3.2m fund also backed by the Royal Bank of Scotland to help an initiative set up by the Scottish government in 2012 continue until the end of 2017. It will offer grants and loans to businesses selected via a Dragons Den-style pitching process.

"There is a funding gap for these early stage businesses. The banks are not filling it and we can't expect them to do it as this is the riskiest part of finance," said Hunter.

He believes the help is necessary because "Scotland lags behind in terms of starting and growing businesses and that is an important part of economic progress."

But asked if things might be better under an independent Scotland Hunter said: "I think that's a hard question to answer. It's a step into the unknown. Whatever the people decide we'll just get on with it. That's democracy."

Hunter has refused to reveal how he will vote in the referendum on whether Scotland should break away from the rest of the UK on 18 September. Instead he has funded a website and ebook which collate information from experts on the pros and cons of independence.

"I'm not going to come down on one side, I am playing this straight. I'm not involved in any of the campaigns. For the past 25 years I have been banging the drum for helping Scottish businesses: this (fund) is part of that. If any side tried to make politicial gain out of it I would be very annoyed," he said.

The new cash from Hunter and RBS will help develop the Scottish Edge fund which has so far support 69 start-up businesses. The Scottish government has already committed £2.35m to the project. But Hunter said that successful applicants would get more than just cash – they will also get advice and mentoring from experienced business people including him.

Hunter has certainly seen both the highs and lows of entrepreneurial enterprise having made his name as Scotland's first billionaire after building up and selling on the retail chain Sports Division for a quarter of a million pounds before building a portfolio of property investments and stakes in a string of retailers including Wyevale Garden Centre and fashion chain USC and footwear store Office. But he lost an estimated quarter of his fortune during the financial crisis as several of those businesses got into financial difficulties.

"I made big mistakes and I take full responsibility. I was never on my knees but my pride took a hit and I'm now a bit poorer and a lot wiser," he says. "Anybody who says the entrepreneurial journey is a straight curve upwards only is wrong. It's a roller coaster and if I couldn't deal with it myself then I wouldn't be much of a man."

Having made his name and much of his fortune from retail, the entrepreneur now doesn't own any store chains, having sold his stake in the House of Fraser department store to Newcastle United and Sports Direct boss Mike Ashley in a controversial move in April this year. Ashley still owns the 11% stake as the sale of the business to Chinese conglomerate Sanpower is yet to be finalised. The deal is thought to be awaiting Chinese regulatory approval.

"It was very straightforward. I checked if I could sell my shares, I could sell them and I got paid. The rest of the shareholders haven't got paid yet. There was a lot of talk about a legal wrangle but nothing ever came of it," said Hunter.

His main investments now are in retail software company OrderDynamics as well as property investments including a portfolio floated on London's junior Aim market in June this year.

webTitle: Latest Royal Mail 'bungle' is a stick too far to beat Cable with

fields.bodyText: There has been great sport to be had poking fun at the business secretary, Vince Cable, for the way he and his department floated Royal Mail – some of which you may even have read here. But there is a danger of picking up any stick to beat a dog. For instance, on Tuesday it was reported that a new row over the float was about to erupt as ministers had forfeited a further "£500m gain for the public purse" after considering selling the government's remaining stake when the shares were trading close to their post-privatisation peak. Chuka Umunna, the shadow business secretary, duly said the disclosure offered further evidence that the privatisation of Royal Mail had been "botched". It is certainly true that in March Cable's advisers gave him a list of scenarios about what to do with the state's remaining 30% holding, which included discussing the government breaking a contract that ostensibly prevented it selling shares before April. At that time, the government's stake was worth about £450m more than now, so theoretically this chance was missed. But Cable had been unswerving in his public comments about the price Royal Mail was listed at, and memorably told a select committee he believed the surging share price immediately following the float to be "froth". To go from that position to breaking the lock-up agreement and announcing the sale of a 30% stake, would have quickly led the City to an obvious conclusion: the government knew something it didn't about the current finances of the postal service, and was trying to dump its stake at the top of the market. It is possible, of course, that the shares could still have risen at that moment – stock markets can do curious things. But faced with such a dramatic U-turn from Cable, plus the prospect of 300m more shares in the market, it looks more likely that Royal Mail shares might have crashed. So much more likely, in fact, that even the minister's team of genius advisers might have predicted it.

webTitle: BHP Billiton spins off metals and mining assets

fields.standfirst: The move, which effectively unwinds its 2001 mega-merger, will trigger another huge payday for banks
fields.body:
One of the financial world's largest ever mergers was effectively unwound on Tuesday as BHP Billiton said it was demerging key assets from its $190bn (£114bn) mining conglomerate – triggering another huge payday for the banks.

The move effectively reverses the 2001 tie-up between BHP and Billiton, a deal which at the time created a near $30bn company and allowed bankers and lawyers to charge $92m for their advice.

Paul Gait, an analyst at Wall Street broker Bernstein, said: "The main beneficiary of the proposed demerger would appear to be the multitude of advisers that will no doubt require significant compensation for helping structure the deal. In the absence of a compelling valuation case for the demerger it is unclear how BHP's existing shareholders will be compensated for this cost."

The latest transaction sees Goldman Sachs leading a team of investment banks – which reportedly also includes UBS, the Swiss bank that was the main adviser to BHP on the 2001 transaction, as well as Gresham, which represented Billiton on the original deal. The mining group declined to say how much it would be paying its advisers this time.

After 13 years as a combined entity, the miner now plans to hive off a collection of unwanted aluminium, coal, silver and manganese mines and plants into a separate company.

Garry White of stockbrokers Charles Stanley said: "Although not an exact match, the move effectively undoes the 2001 mega-merger that created the company, with most of the assets in the spin-off being traced back to Billiton. Indeed, it could be argued that, with hindsight, the 2001 merger was a boon for Billiton shareholders, but not so much for investors in Broken Hill Proprietary Company."

Billiton's main assets in the 2001 merger were the Hillside and Bayside aluminium smelters in Richards Bay on South Africa's east coast, the Mozal smelter in neighbouring Mozambique, and energy coal mines in South Africa – all of which will make up part of the new company. Meanwhile, shortly after the merger, BHP's main assets of iron ore, copper, coking coal and oil suddenly found themselves in booming markets as prices soared on the back of surging Chinese demand.

BHP Billiton said that once it had simplified the group it will be almost exclusively focused on its large iron ore, copper, coal, petroleum and potash businesses. "With fewer assets and a greater upstream focus, the group will be able to reduce costs and improve the productivity of its largest businesses more quickly," the company's statement said. "As a result, its portfolio is expected to generate stronger growth in free cash flow and a superior return on investment".

The chairman, Jac Nasser, added: "For over a century, BHP Billiton has progressively reshaped its business to maintain its industry leadership. We believe the proposed demerger, if implemented, will accelerate the simplification of the group's portfolio, provide investors with choice and unlock value in both companies. Our shareholders will have the opportunity to vote on this proposal once the necessary approvals are in place".

Despite Nasser's upbeat tone, BHP Billiton shares shed almost 5% on the announcement, losing 102p to £19.65, as investors reacted to the streamlining of their company.

Existing shareholders will be given shares in a new company containing the demerged assets, although the business will be listed in Australia and South Africa. This move is likely to create an added complication for UK fund managers, many of whom have mandates that only allow them to own shares in British companies.

Andrew Mackenzie, BHP Billiton chief executive, added: "The assets that would form the new company are not of the same size as those in our major basins but many are among the largest and highest quality in their sectors. We believe they will be more valuable in a purpose built, independent company than they would be in BHP Billiton. With experienced management and a strategy and cost structure tailored to the scale of its businesses, the demerged company would be well placed to create substantial additional value for shareholders and rewarding careers for employees."

However, Albert Minassian, an analyst at Investec, said: "Although we are cautious on divestments involving such a broad range of commodities done at a low point of those assets' earnings cycle we think this strategy makes sense but struggle to show significant increase in value compared to our existing estimates".

webTitle: Carillion raises merger offer for Balfour Beatty

fields.standfirst: The British construction firm's latest offer, valuing engineering company Balfour at £2.1bn, comes after two were rejected
fields.body:
British construction firm Carillion has raised for the third time its merger proposal for engineering company Balfour Beatty, with new terms that value its rival at £2.1bn.

Carillion said under the new offer Balfour shareholders would have 58.3% of the combined firm. They would also get a cash dividend of 8.5p per share.

The raised offer came after talks with Balfour's biggest shareholders in the past week. Its negotiations with Balfour's board ended last month after the two sides clashed over the sale of Balfour's US engineering and design business Parsons Brinckerhoff.

Balfour, which built the aquatics centre for London 2012 and is transforming the Olympic stadium, has said it expects to sell Parsons Brinckerhoff for between £580m and £650m but Carillion insisted in earlier talks the sale should be cancelled.

Niall Dineen, portfolio manager at City investor AGF International Advisors and a shareholder in both the companies, said the improvement in the offer should be enough to get Balfour Beatty to engage.

"The Carillion argument regarding synergies seems sensible, the Carillion idea of keeping the Parsons Brinckerhoff business seems sensible and the improvement in the offer should be enough to get Balfour Beatty to engage with them," he said.

Carillion's previous proposal would have given Balfour Beatty shareholders 56.5% of the combined group, based on the current undiluted ordinary share capital of each company, it said. Balfour has rejected two takeover proposals by Carillion to create a giant that could compete for major international contracts against the likes of Spain's Ferrovial.

As well as the showcase Olympics buildings, Balfour is involved in the 30-year M25 road widening project and has rebuilt Blackfriars railway station in London.

Balfour said it would consider the new offer and make a further announcement in due course.

Carillion had been given a deadline of August 21 by British authorities to "put up or shut up", and the company urged Balfour to request an extension for discussions to continue.

webTitle: Soaring shipping measure signals improving health of global economy

fields.bodyText: A measure of global trade has soared over the past fortnight, signalling a possible return to health of the world economy. The Baltic Dry daily index of shipping costs has jumped by more than 40% in a month, soaring to 1,042 since it hit a post crash low of 732 in July. The jump in prices for sending freight goods around the world indicates that shipping firms are seeing a sharp rise in demand for their services. Figures from Lloyds List show the index performed badly throughout 2013 and the first half of 2014, when many shipping companies reported losing money on each container ship, many of which sailed half empty. A gentle rise in prices charged by shippers since early July has accelerated in the last two weeks, taking many analysts by surprise. Jim Leaviss, head of fixed interest at M&G Investments, said: "Although it's a pretty volatile indicator there is a strong relationship between the cost of shipping bulk cargo – generally intermediate goods like metals – and the strength of the global economy. So the recent 40% rise in the Baltic Dry Index might well be telling us that the global recovery is back on track after a pretty patchy first half of 2014." Leaviss added that the timing of the Russian sanctions against the EU and the rise in the index might not be a coincidence, possibly reflecting that Russia might be having to ship goods, including food, from further away now that it cannot import from the EU. David Blanchflower, professor of economics at Dartmouth College, New Hampshire, and a former Bank of England policymaker, said the Baltic Dry was traditionally a key indicator of the health of global economy, illustrated by the sharp fall in the index between May and December of 2008. "The fall in 2008 was the most catastrophic collapse of any indicator in the Great Recession. The question now is, does it indicate a turnaround? The rise might be driven by an increase in demand, or a fall in ship supply, or both." On Monday one of the major container shipping organisations urged fleet owners to raise rates on their Asia to US routes by at least $600 per 40-foot container, an increase of 14% from current levels. Transpacific Stabilisation Agreement (TSA), a lobby group for operators between the US and Asia, said the planned increase followed strong cargo demand and higher capacity levels in recent months, which forward bookings suggest will continue through September. Its members include 15 of the world's biggest container shipping lines such as Denmark's Maersk Line, a unit of A.P. Moller-Maersk, privately owned Switzerland-based Mediterranean Shipping Company (MSC), French privately held CMA CGM, China's COSCO Shipping and Korea's Hanjin Shipping. TSA executive administrator Brian Conrad said prices should go up from 1 September to reflect higher demand and offset losses from last year. "Lines have made modest revenue gains to date this year, but they continue to struggle in terms of returning to profitability," he said. The container shipping industry has been struggling as vessel capacity has outstripped the volumes of goods for transport in the global economic downturn. More than 90% of the world's trade is carried by sea, but the overcapacity meant freight rates plunged to unprofitable levels for most carriers in 2013. Spot freight rates are calculated and published every week by Shanghai Shipping Exchange. Last week rates for transport of 40-foot containers from Asia to the U.S. West Coast stood at $4,218. The Baltic Dry, which is a composite of costs across all major shipping routes, is issued daily by the London-based Baltic Exchange and provides "an assessment of the price of moving the major raw materials by sea". Mearsk parent, AP Møller-Maersk, gave a further indication of a return to health on global shipping route after it said better than expected profits in the second quarter of the year meant it would offer shareholders a £1bn buyback. The Danish owner of the world's largest container shipping line also upgraded its prediction of full year profits to more than $4.5bn, up from its already raised forecast of $4bn three months ago. Maersk Line, which transports about 15% of seaborne freight, is considered a good proxy for global trade.

fields.body:
5.02pm BST

European markets end higher again

With hopes that tensions between Russia and Ukraine could be easing, leading shares have recorded another day of gains. The FTSE 100 has hit a three week high - details in Nick Fletcher’s closing market report - while European markets have also moved higher, as have US shares. Inflation data from the UK and US suggested there was not likely to be an imminent rise in interest rates although stronger than expected US housing starts muddied the picture. And there could be further volatility with Bank of England minutes on Wednesday and speeches from Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen and ECB boss Mario Draghi at the Jackson Hole get-together on Friday. Meanwhile the closing stock market scores were:

  • The FTSE 100 finished 38.06 points or 0.56% higher at 6779.31
  • Germany’s Dax rose 0.96% to 9334.28
  • France’s Cac climbed 0.56% to 4254.45
  • Italy’s FTSE MIB edged up 0.02% to 19,644.37
  • Spain’s Ibex ended 0.32% better at 10,386.5

In the US, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 70 points or 0.42% higher.

And on that note, it’s time to close up for the evening. Thanks for your comments and we’ll be back tomorrow.

Updated at 5.02pm BST

3.22pm BST

Carillion sweetens its offer for Balfour Beatty

Back in the City, an ongoing takeover battle has just taken another twist.

Construction company Carillion announced that its raised its offer for rival Balfour Beatty. It’s now offering a 36% premium to Balfour’s share price in late July, before merger plans were made public.

Carillion said it had made the new offer “following discussions with Balfour Beatty’s major shareholders”, which piles more pressure on Balfour’s management to return to the negotiating table.

For talks to take place, though, Balfour would have to ask the Takeover Panel to extend its ‘put up or shut up’ deadline, of this Thursday. The clock is ticking....

3.13pm BST

Elizabeth Arden posts biggest loss ever

In other news, Elizabeth Arden’s new celebrity perfumes have failed to wow the public.

The cosmetics chain reported its biggest fall in profits ever, after quarterly sales tumbled by over 28%.

Elizabeth Arden, which sells celebrity perfumes from the likes of Justin Bieber and Taylor Swift, also warned that weak sales would continue for the next six months

Shares have tumbled by 25% today - not the sweet smell of success that investors were looking for.

2.52pm BST

Wall Street up

America’s stock market has opened in positive territory, after the latest US inflation data showed little signs of inflationary pressures building.

Traders also showed relief that there’s been no further escalation in tensions between Russia and Ukraine.

The Nasdaq index, heavy with tech stocks, hit a new 14-year high in early trading, while the Dow Jones is up 0.25%.

Most European markets are also holding their earlier gains, led by the German DAX, up around 1%.

2.26pm BST

Back on this side of the Atlantic, a judge has sharply criticised the Bank of Scotland for double-charging mortgage holders in Northern Ireland who were behind in their payments

Henry McDonald, Ireland Correspondent, reports:

In a judgement released in Belfast today judge Master Ellison accused the bank of unfair accounting over double billing some of its customers for mortgages.

He said: “There may not be any fraud involved, but I would certainly not regard this as fair accounting.”

The judge excoriated the bank and its offshoots, including Halifax, after three Northern Ireland customers took cases against it.

Such practices to punish late payments on mortgages had “plunged into depression” many home owners in distress.

Overall the bank’s behaviour had been “unconscionable”, the judge concluded.

The Housing Rights Service (HRS) in Northern Ireland took up the cases on behalf of three mortgage holders. It said if the bank’s practice had gone unchallenged, many borrowers would have lost their homes.

One of the people whom the HRS acted for was a female bank worker who fell behind on her mortgage because she had to leave her home as she was being targeted by criminals. In addition her partner tied while she was out of house. As a result she fell behind on her mortgage payments and was later forced to make monthly payments above the original contracted amount for more than one year.

Christopher McGrath, a lawyer acting for HRS, said: “The court has stated that the handling of accounts by Bank of Scotland in these instances, created ‘a mist of incomprehension, confusion and self -contradiction’.

“It is our view that this practice unfettered would undoubtedly have resulted in many borrowers unnecessarily losing their home.”

A Lloyds Banking Group spokesperson said the bank was considering the judgement and will “respond accordingly” when it has fully reviewed the findings. It owns Bank of Scotland-Halifax, which is a major bank for home owners in Northern Ireland.

The spokesperson added that the bank encourages customers to contact them at the earliest opportunity if they believe that they will be unable to make their monthly mortgage payment.

2.01pm BST

Euro hits nine-month low against the US dollar

The surge in the US housing sector has pushed the dollar up against other major currencies.

This sent the euro sliding to a nine-month low of $1.3318.

That could be quietly welcomed in the European Central Bank, as the euro’s strength has been one factor pushing down eurozone inflation (to just 0.4%).

1.48pm BST

Never mind inflation, look at those housing starts!

America has also seen a surge in new house-building projects, in a sign that the economy picked up last month.

Housing starts (the number of new home building projects) jumped by 15% in July to an annual rate of 1.093m. up from 945,000 in June.

And the number of new permits being granted to home-builders also rose sharply, to an annual rate of 1.052m, from 973k.

Demand for new multi-occupancy units (think apartments) led the revival.

1.40pm BST

US consumer prices rise 0.1% in July

America’s inflation crept up a little last month, as higher food and rent costs were countered by a drop in energy costs.

Consumer prices rose by 0.1% in July, the smallest rise in five months.

The annual CPI index was 2.0% higher than a year ago. That’s down on June’s 2.1%.

Food prices jumped by 0.4% during the month, while housing costs rose by 0.2%.

Energy costs, though, fell by 0.3%, as did the price of gasoline at the pumps, reflecting the recent drop in the oil price.

Core CPI, stripping out food and energy, was unchanged at +0.1% month-on-month. That’s a weaker rise than economists had predicted.

At first glance, there’s little sign of inflationary pressures that would force the Federal Reserve into changing its view of the US economy, and the likely pace of rate rises.

I’ll pull together some reaction now....

Updated at 2.40pm BST

1.28pm BST

One down, one to go.... We’re about to get the US inflation date for July.

Economists predict that the Consumer Price Index could come in at 2.0%, down from 2.1% in June.

Business Insider’s preview explains:

Expectations are for CPI to rise 0.1% month-over-month, and 2% year-over-year.

“Core” CPI, which excludes food and gas — which tend to be more volatile — is expected to rise 0.2% over last month and 1.9% over last year.

1.21pm BST

UK inflation a summary

Recap time, before the latest US inflation data hits the wires.

The UK inflation rate has fallen sharply, as clothing sales pulled back the rising cost of living.

The Consumer Prices Index fell to 1.6%, a bigger drop than expected, with food prices also falling.

The Office for National Statistics found that clothing prices tumbled by 5.9% month-on-month in July, as high street shops belatedly got their summer sales under way.

Firms also reported that the cost of raw materials fell.

The government parties have argued that the recent drop in inflation shows that their policies are paying off. The opposition Labour party, though, said the weak wage growth (just 0.6% at present, or -0.2% including bonuses) means real pay is still falling.

Full political reaction here.

Martin Beck, senior economic adviser to the EY ITEM Club, predicts that inflation will remain below the 2% target for several months:

“The inflation environment remains benign. After their Iraq-related rally, oil prices have dropped sharply over the past month, with Brent dropping below $100 a barrel yesterday for the first time in fifteen months. And though the pound has weakened a little of late, it remains much higher than earlier in the year, which is helping to subdue import prices. Furthermore, today’s data suggest that – if anything – the pressures coming along the supply chain are disinflationary. This all adds up to inflation remaining close to 1½% over the second half of the year.”

The game of predicting when the Bank of England might raise interest rates took another spin, with economists explained that the fall in inflation makes a pre-Christmas hike less likely.

Here’s our news story: UK inflation fall to 1.6% lessens likelihood of interest rate rise

Echoing that theory, the pound tumbled on the news, shedding almost a whole cent against the US dollar to a four-month low $1.6633.

Andy Scott, spokesperson for FX advisory services at foreign currency specialists, HiFX, explains:

“Despite the economy growing at its fastest pace in several years and unemployment falling to its lowest level since the end of 2008, employees are receiving wage increases below the current rate of inflation, resulting in a squeeze on annual earnings in real terms. This indicates that there may indeed be additional slack in the labour market that needs to be used up in order for pay to keep up with inflation and gives the BoE scope to continue to keep rates on hold.

Another factor that’s probably winning the argument against raising rates too soon is that some of the world’s major economies either contracted or saw minimal growth in the last quarter. This could weigh somewhat on the UK economy in the coming months, particularly with such a gloomy picture in the eurozone.”

The Retail Price Index, the wider measure of inflation, dropped slightly to 2.5% in July. That means that rail fares in England and Wales are likely to rise by 3.5% on average, and up to 5.5% in some cases, in 2015.

The chancellor, though, could yet cap rises at a lower rate....

The ONS also reported that UK house prices hit a new record high in June, although the pace of growth moderated.

Updated at 1.30pm BST

12.53pm BST

Larry Elliott: UK inflation figures - say goodbye to your pay rise

2014 was meant to be the year when real UK wages started growing, and interest rates rose. But it’s not working out that way.

Our economics editor, Larry Elliott, writes:

Even with July’s drop in inflation [to 1.6%], prices are still rising faster than earnings, which are going up at an annual rate of 0.6%. At the start of the year there was a lot of talk about how 2014 was going to be the year of the pay rise. That now looks unlikely. Living standards will carry on falling deep into the autumn even if wages do start to pick up.

Some City analysts think 2014 will also be the year of the interest rate rise. That, too, is starting to look questionable given not just the weakness of CPI inflation but also the lack of any real price pressure in the pipeline. The producer prices index, a guide to the costs paid by manufacturers and the price of goods leaving factory gates, shows that the drop in fuel and raw material costs together with tight control of pay is allowing firms to cut tariff prices.

An interest rate rise by the end of the year – November being the likeliest date – should not be ruled out, but it will be on the basis of what the Bank of England’s monetary policy committee thinks is going to happen to inflation rather than what is actually happening.

More here: UK inflation figures - say goodbye to your pay rise

12.18pm BST

12.06pm BST

The political reaction

Today’s inflation figures have been grasped by both sides of the political spectrum.

The Treasury claims that today’s fall in the Consumer Prices Index, from 1.9% to 1.6%, is a sign that its policies are bearing fruit. A spokesperson said:

“The government’s long term economic plan is working, with today marking the 7th consecutive month that inflation has been below the Bank of England’s two per cent target.

“But the effects of the great recession are still being felt and so we have taken continued action to help with the cost of living, including cutting income tax, freezing fuel duty and reducing the costs of childcare. The job is not yet done so the government will go on making the realistic assessment of what needs to be done to deliver a brighter economic future”

Liberal Democrat Chief Secretary to the Treasury, Danny Alexander, told Sky News:

“The fact that inflation has been below the Bank of England target for seven consecutive months shows that subdued inflation is now becoming the norm as the economy recovers.

“Eliminating the deficit fairly, and repairing the UK economy remains central to the role of Liberal Democrats in Government.

“These encouraging inflation numbers should give businesses the confidence they need to deliver the investment required to boost productivity. Rising productivity is the only route to sustainable increases in living standards.”

The opposition Labour party, meanwhile, points out that real incomes are still shrinking. Cathy Jamieson MP, Shadow Treasury Minister, says:

“While this fall in the rate of inflation is welcome, the squeeze on working people continues.

“The latest figures show regular pay rising by just 0.6 per cent - less than half the rate of inflation announced today. Wages after inflation have now fallen by over £1,600 a year under this government.

“Labour’s economic plan will deal with the cost-of-living crisis, make Britain better off and earn our way to higher living standards for all, not just a few.”

11.42am BST

Patrick Collinson: Chancellor could block inflation-busting fare increases

Our Money editor Patrick Collinson has hit the phones, and confirms that rail fare rises in 2014 could be lower than the 3.5% that is widely expected.

As flagged up in my last post, it’s all down to George Osborne....

Over to Patrick:

This morning virtually every story on rail fares is assuming that prices for ‘regulated’ fares will rise by 3.5% from next year, using the formula of July’s RPI figure plus 1%. But there is absolutely no guarantee that will be the outcome. In the autumn statement last year, the Chancellor cancelled the RPI+1% increase scheduled for January 2014, replacing it with just a straightforward RPI increase. What will happen in January 2015? We know that the RPI figure will be used - but whether it will be +1% or zero, or something else, is for now speculative.

This morning, a Department for Transport spokesman said: “No decisions on fare rises for 2015 have yet been taken. We understand people’s concerns about the cost of travel and the impact this has on family budgets. That is why for 2014 we reduced average fare rises to RPI plus 0% for the first time in a decade.”

The reality is that the DfT do not know precisely when a decision will be taken on the level of increases for 2015, as it is ultimately a Treasury decision. In this year’s pre-election autumn statement, the chancellor could rule out inflation-plus increases, switch to the CPI measure used for welfare benefits, or even revert to the formula used in the years immediately after rail privatisation, when fares went up by RPI minus 1%.

That would be a popular move, especially with Britons heading to the polling booths in May 2015....

11.32am BST

One point to flag up... George Osborne could offer Britain’s rail travellers a reprieve from these hefty price rises in 2015.

Last autumn, the chancellor capped average regulated fare increases at RPI, rather than RPI + 1% (up to RPI +3 for some fares).

Potentially, Osborne could extend this freeze for another year...

11.24am BST

We’re collecting expert reaction to today’s inflation data here:

UK inflation - what the economists say

11.23am BST

Food prices fell a little between July and June, led by bread & cereals and sugar, jam, syrups, chocolate & confectionery.

That’s due to the ongoing price wars between major supermarkets, as established chains try to battle Aldi and Lidl.

Mark Billige, managing Partner at pricing experts Simon-Kucher & Partners, explains:

Whilst lower grocery prices are good news for consumers, they will be putting the margins of supermarkets and their suppliers under enormous pressure with a knock on effect on share prices. We expect this trend to continue as the discounters continue increasing their market share.”

11.19am BST

Alasdair Cavalla, economist at the CEBR, agrees that UK interest rates are unlikely to rise this year:

A long stretch of below-target inflation increases the likelihood that the Bank of England will raise interest rates in early 2015 rather than this year. Spare capacity, which is the Bank’s stated guiding factor in its decision, is remaining higher for longer than expected.

Cavalla points out that price growth is weak across the global economy:

The Eurozone has been falling ever closer to deflation, while the European Central Bank is facing strong Bundesbank opposition to any monetary loosening measures. US inflation data come out later today, but at just 2.1% on the latest reading and expected to be at 2.0% today, the rate is already below the long-term average.

In addition, a strong pound means that the UK economy finds imported goods even cheaper. Therefore, recent signals suggest the Bank seems likely to wait until next year before raising the base rate.

11.02am BST

11.01am BST

UK inflation - reaction starts here

The Bank of England a good excuse to keep its hands off the interest rate-raising lever until the new year, says Jake Trask, corporate dealer at UKForex.

With dovish comments from BoE Governor Mark Carney last week, this fall in inflation will provide the MPC with even more reason to hold out for Q1 2015 before tightening monetary policy. We may learn more tomorrow about the intended timeframe for a rate hike when the minutes of the latest MPC meeting are released.”

10.57am BST

Here’s transport correspondent Gwyn Topham on the implications of today’s inflation data for rail passengers:

Rail fares will rise by an average of 3.5% in January with some fares rising by up to 5.5%, adding hundreds of pounds to the cost of season tickets.

Labour and transport campaigners are stepping up their challenge to the railway system, with protests taking place at stations across the country as the extent of planned fare rises for 2015 is revealed.

Campaigners have demanded action to tackle above-inflation fare increases, pointing out that ticket prices are rising nearly four times faster than wages and average fares will have risen 25% under the coalition government.

Regulated train fares are pegged to July’s retail price inflation figure of 2.5% and capped at RPI+1% – although train operators may raise fares on some routes by an extra 2%. The flex rule means some fares could rise by 5.5% – and could add more than £300 to the cost of annual season tickets on the most expensive commuter routes.

Cumulatively, prices will have gone up almost 25% during the current parliament, while average wages have risen by 6.9%. According to the Campaign for Better Transport commuters are spending up to a fifth of their income on season tickets.

More here: Rail fares to rise by average of 3.5% in January

I believe, though, that Scottish fares will rise by just 2.5% -- control of rail north of the border has been devolved to the Scottish government.

10.32am BST

Britain’s double-digit house price inflation (see last entry) is a blow to those hoping to get into the housing ladder.

Campbell Robb, the chief executive of housing charity Shelter, has urged the government to do more:

“Today’s house price hike is yet another blow for people across the country desperate to put down roots and create a stable home.

“No matter how hard people work or save, millions are being priced out of a home of their own, caught in the ‘rent trap’ and constantly moving from one expensive property to the next.

“The only solution is for politicians to roll up their sleeves and build the affordable homes we so desperately need. From a new generation of part rent part buy homes, to encouraging smaller builders back into the market, there are ways to fix this country’s housing crisis.“If we don’t see radical action soon, more and more people will be left without a hope of ever building a stable future in a home of their own.”

10.20am BST

We also have data showing that UK house price growth slowed a little at the start of the summer.

The average house price rose by 10.2% in the 12 months to June, according to the ONS. That’s down from 10.4% in the year to May.

It says:

  • House price annual inflation was 10.7% in England, 3.5% in Wales, 6.0% in Scotland and 4.9% in Northern Ireland. House prices are increasing strongly across most parts of the UK, with prices in London again showing the highest growth.

    • Average prices in the capital have surged by 19.3% over the last 12 months, and are now a staggering 35.6% higher than the pre-financial crisis peak in January 2008.

    But more recent data has suggested that sellers in London are now cutting prices; a sign the market may be cooling off...

    10.03am BST

    Read the report yourself

    The inflation data is online here.

    10.02am BST

    There are also signs that British firms face less inflationary pressure.

    Producer input prices (basically, what firms pay for raw materials) dropped 1.6% month-on-month in July, and are a chunky 7.3% lower than a year ago.

    Output prices (what they charge for their goods) fell slightly too.

    9.59am BST

    The 5.7% drop in clothing prices last month came from “a wide range of men’s, women’s and children’s outerwear, for example trousers, coats and jumpers”, the ONS adds.

    9.54am BST

    The chances of the Bank of England raising interest rates in 2014 have fallen, flags up Jeremy Cook of currency firm World First:

    Updated at 9.54am BST

    9.50am BST

    UK inflation, the details

    So, why the big drop in inflation last month?

    The Office for National Statistics says that the biggest single factor driving CPI down to 1.6% was clothing prices, which tumbled by 5.7% between June and July.

    That suggests that summer clothing sales kicked off in earnest in July, after being delayed from June.

    Other large downward effects came from the alcohol, financial services and food & non-alcoholic drinks.

    The ONS explains:

    Alcohol & tobacco prices, overall, fell by 0.7% between June and July this year but rose by 0.6% a year ago. The downward effect came from a range of alcohol products, principally spirits and wine. For both groups, prices fell this year but rose a year ago.

    But transport costs rose, by 1.3% between June and July.

    9.44am BST

    9.43am BST

    Pound falls after UK inflation rate slows

    The pound has taken a tumble as City traders react to the larger-than-expected fall in inflation last month.

    It’s down 0.5%, or 0.8 of a cent, at $1.665, as the guessing game of when the Bank of England will raise interest rates takes another twist.

    9.41am BST

    Summary

    Here’s some instant reaction to the news that the headline UK inflation rate fell by more than expected in July:

    9.36am BST

    RPI dips to 2.5% -- rail fares will be affected

    The Retail Prices Index, a broader measure of inflation, has also fallen, to 2.5% in July.

    That means average rail fares will rise by 3.5% next year, under the government’s RPI +1% formula.

    But rail operators are allowed to raise some fares by as much as RPI +3%, meaning some unlucky commuters face paying 5.5% extra in 2015.

    Updated at 9.38am BST

    9.31am BST

    UK inflation falls to 1.6% in July

    Breaking: The UK consumer prices index has tumbled to 1.6% in July, a sharp fall on June’s 1.9%.

    That should bring some relief to households, and also takes inflation further away from the Bank of England’s target of 2% inflation.

    But prices are still rising almost three times faster than wages --- average earnings in the UK rose by just 0.6% in the April-June quarter, according to the latest data.

    Lots more detail and reaction to follow....

    9.23am BST

    The pound just fell against the US dollar, down 0.3 of a cent at $1.6694.

    Does that mean someone is anticipating a weak inflation reading in a few minutes time?....

    9.21am BST

    UK inflation, a preamble

    Nearly time for the UK inflation data for July.

    As flagged up earlier, economists expect the UK Consumer Prices Index to have fallen a little, to 1.8% from 1.9% in June.

    Britain currently has the highest inflation rate in Europe, with several members of the eurozone experiencing falling prices.

    9.14am BST

    European shares rise again

    European stock markets are showing small gains across the board, as hopes of easing geopolitical tensions cheer the City.

    The FTSE 100 has gained 0.5%, or 33 points, to 6775, despite BHP Billiton (-3.5%) dragging down the index as its demerger plans sink in.

    Germany’s DAX has gained 1%, on hopes that Russia and Ukraine may reach an agreement to end the long-running, deadly clashes on their borders. The French CAC is up 0.44%.

    The Footsie being led by housebuilder Barratt Developments - which may be benefitting from strong results from rival Persimmon this morning.

    Persimmon, which builds homes outside the M25, reported a 57% jump in profits for the first half of 2014.

    The firm said the “ongoing improvement in the UK’s economic performance” was helping the sector, and claimed there was “little sign” of fatigue, despite recent signs that mortgage lending may be cooling off. Full story here.

    8.49am BST

    Rumours of a pact between the Bank of England and the UK Treasury to resist raising interest rates until after next May’s general election refuse to go away.

    City AM reports that the Treasury committee will ask governor Mark Carney about his relationship with George Osborne, after two MPs raised concerns over the closeness of their relationship.

    The BoE and the Treasury have tried to rubbish talk of a secret pact. But as committee member Mark Garniere explained, this speculation could be damaging:

    “The Bank of England has to act independently, otherwise the whole thing becomes farcical – you get back to the worst case scenario where the chancellor is deciding rates covertly....

    “The Treasury committee is very cognisant of this kind of risk.”

    8.39am BST

    Overnight, a former trader at Dutch bank Rabobank became the first Britain to plead guilty to charges over the Libor scandal.

    Paul Robson had been accused of taking part in a scheme to manipulate the “yen Libor rate” - a benchmark rate at which banks would lend to each other.

    The US justice department said Robson had pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and bank fraud. Leslie Caldwell, who heads the Justice Department’s criminal division, said:

    “The scope of the fraud was massive, but the scheme was simple. By illegally influencing the Libor rates, Robson and his co-conspirators rigged the markets to ensure that their trades made money.”

    Robson is the second Rabobank trader to plead guilty following probes into the alleged manipulation of interest rate benchmarks.

    More here: Ex-Rabobank trader second to plead guilty to Libor rigging

    8.28am BST

    BHP Billiton shares drop as demerger plan announced

    Shares in BHP Billiton, the Anglo-Australian mining giant, have promptly dropped by 3% in early trading after it announced plans to spin off its aluminium, coal, manganese, nickel and silver assets into a new company.

    It’s a massive demerger -- which appears to unpick much of the deal that created the group in 2001.

    Jac Nasser, BHP chairman, says the deal will “provide investors with choice and unlock value in both companies.”

    8.21am BST

    Rail campaigners have already warned that fares are rising too fast, even before today’s inflation data is released.

    The Campaign for Better Transport argues that the “Retail Prices Index +1%” formula (or RPI + 3% for some fares) needs to change, as some commuters could pay an extra £300 each next year.

    Spokesman Martin Abrams isn’t impressed that some fares could rise by around 5.6% (depending on today’s data, of course!):

    “With people’s wages stagnating, and in some cases falling, the expense of taking the train to work has become a huge part of living costs.

    If the government doesn’t put an end to above-inflation fare increases quickly, ordinary commuters will be priced off the train and could be forced into agonising decisions such as moving house or quitting their jobs”

    More here: Labour and transport campaigners step up rail fares fight as prices rise again

    Updated at 8.24am BST

    8.05am BST

    Inflation data in focus

    Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, business and the eurozone.

    Inflation is high on the agenda, with new surveys showing the cost of living in Britain and America due out today.

    The UK’s Consumer Prices Index index is expected to fall a little, after spiking unexpectedly last month. Economists predict CPI will dip to 1.8% in July, from 1.9%, at 9.30am.

    That would mean prices were running three times faster than average wages (which rose just 0.6% in the three months to June). Cue plenty more justifiable concern that the UK recovery hasn’t reached workers’ pockets.

    Today’s inflation data is particularly important for UK commuters, as the wider Retail Prices Index will be used to calculate next year’s rail fare increases.

    RPI is expected to be unchanged at 2.6%. Rail operators are allowed to increase fares by an average of RPI + 1%. But under a “flex” rule, train companies can raise some fares by another 2% above the average, as long as they make cuts elsewhere.

    So some passengers could face an inflation-busting 5.6% increase, even if the service isn’t that much better....

    America’s July inflation data is due at 1.30pm BST (8.30am New York), and is also expected to show a slight drop. That could reduce the pressure on the US Federal Reserve to start raising interest rates, as it comes to the end of its bond-buying stimulus programme.

    CMC Market’s Michael Hewson explains:

    In the afternoon session we also get the latest US CPI inflation numbers and they are expected to slip slightly from the 2.1% in June to 2% in July.

    A similarly weak number would undermine the recent rise in the US dollar as markets bet that rates are likely to remain lower for longer.

    In the corporate world, mining giant BHP Billiton has just announced plans to spin off many of its operations into a new “Global Metals and Mining Company”. More on that shortly.

    Stock markets are expected to continue where they stopped yesterday, rising on hopes that the Ukraine crisis is easing. Last night, the US Nasdaq index hit its highest closing level in 14 years (a peak that was swiftly followed by the dot-com crash....).

    And in the City, building firm Persimmon has reported that demand in the housing market remains strong after a leap in profits.

    I’ll be tracking the main developments through the day.

    Updated at 8.11am BST

Back on this side of the Atlantic, a judge has sharply criticised the Bank of Scotland for double-charging mortgage holders in Northern Ireland who were behind in their payments Henry McDonald, Ireland Correspondent, reports: In a judgement released in Belfast today judge Master Ellison accused the bank of unfair accounting over double billing some of its customers for mortgages. He said: “There may not be any fraud involved, but I would certainly not regard this as fair accounting.” The judge excoriated the bank and its offshoots, including Halifax, after three Northern Ireland customers took cases against it. Such practices to punish late payments on mortgages had “plunged into depression” many home owners in distress. Overall the bank’s behaviour had been “unconscionable”, the judge concluded. The Housing Rights Service (HRS) in Northern Ireland took up the cases on behalf of three mortgage holders. It said if the bank’s practice had gone unchallenged, many borrowers would have lost their homes. One of the people whom the HRS acted for was a female bank worker who fell behind on her mortgage because she had to leave her home as she was being targeted by criminals. In addition her partner tied while she was out of house. As a result she fell behind on her mortgage payments and was later forced to make monthly payments above the original contracted amount for more than one year. Christopher McGrath, a lawyer acting for HRS, said: “The court has stated that the handling of accounts by Bank of Scotland in these instances, created ‘a mist of incomprehension, confusion and self -contradiction’. “It is our view that this practice unfettered would undoubtedly have resulted in many borrowers unnecessarily losing their home.” A Lloyds Banking Group spokesperson said the bank was considering the judgement and will “respond accordingly” when it has fully reviewed the findings. It owns Bank of Scotland-Halifax, which is a major bank for home owners in Northern Ireland. The spokesperson added that the bank encourages customers to contact them at the earliest opportunity if they believe that they will be unable to make their monthly mortgage payment. The surge in the US housing sector has pushed the dollar up against other major currencies. This sent the euro sliding to a nine-month low of $1.3318. That could be quietly welcomed in the European Central Bank, as the euro’s strength has been one factor pushing down eurozone inflation (to just 0.4%). America has also seen a surge in new house-building projects, in a sign that the economy picked up last month. Housing starts (the number of new home building projects) jumped by 15% in July to an annual rate of 1.093m. up from 945,000 in June. And the number of new permits being granted to home-builders also rose sharply, to an annual rate of 1.052m, from 973k. Demand for new multi-occupancy units (think apartments) led the revival. America’s inflation crept up a little last month, as higher food and rent costs were countered by a drop in energy costs. Consumer prices rose by 0.1% in July, the smallest rise in five months. The annual CPI index was 2.0% higher than a year ago. That’s down on June’s 2.1%. Food prices jumped by 0.4% during the month, while housing costs rose by 0.2%. Energy costs, though, fell by 0.3%, as did the price of gasoline at the pumps, reflecting the recent drop in the oil price. Core CPI, stripping out food and energy, was unchanged at +0.1% month-on-month. That’s a weaker rise than economists had predicted. At first glance, there’s little sign of inflationary pressures that would force the Federal Reserve into changing its view of the US economy, and the likely pace of rate rises. I’ll pull together some reaction now.... One down, one to go.... We’re about to get the US inflation date for July. Economists predict that the Consumer Price Index could come in at 2.0%, down from 2.1% in June. Business Insider’s preview explains: Expectations are for CPI to rise 0.1% month-over-month, and 2% year-over-year. “Core” CPI, which excludes food and gas — which tend to be more volatile — is expected to rise 0.2% over last month and 1.9% over last year. Recap time, before the latest US inflation data hits the wires. The UK inflation rate has fallen sharply, as clothing sales pulled back the rising cost of living. The Consumer Prices Index fell to 1.6%, a bigger drop than expected, with food prices also falling. The Office for National Statistics found that clothing prices tumbled by 5.9% month-on-month in July, as high street shops belatedly got their summer sales under way. Firms also reported that the cost of raw materials fell. The government parties have argued that the recent drop in inflation shows that their policies are paying off. The opposition Labour party, though, said the weak wage growth (just 0.6% at present, or -0.2% including bonuses) means real pay is still falling. Full political reaction here. Martin Beck, senior economic adviser to the EY ITEM Club, predicts that inflation will remain below the 2% target for several months: “The inflation environment remains benign. After their Iraq-related rally, oil prices have dropped sharply over the past month, with Brent dropping below $100 a barrel yesterday for the first time in fifteen months. And though the pound has weakened a little of late, it remains much higher than earlier in the year, which is helping to subdue import prices. Furthermore, today’s data suggest that – if anything – the pressures coming along the supply chain are disinflationary. This all adds up to inflation remaining close to 1½% over the second half of the year.” The game of predicting when the Bank of England might raise interest rates took another spin, with economists explained that the fall in inflation makes a pre-Christmas hike less likely. Here’s our news story: UK inflation fall to 1.6% lessens likelihood of interest rate rise Echoing that theory, the pound tumbled on the news, shedding almost a whole cent against the US dollar to a four-month low $1.6633. Andy Scott, spokesperson for FX advisory services at foreign currency specialists, HiFX, explains: “Despite the economy growing at its fastest pace in several years and unemployment falling to its lowest level since the end of 2008, employees are receiving wage increases below the current rate of inflation, resulting in a squeeze on annual earnings in real terms. This indicates that there may indeed be additional slack in the labour market that needs to be used up in order for pay to keep up with inflation and gives the BoE scope to continue to keep rates on hold. Another factor that’s probably winning the argument against raising rates too soon is that some of the world’s major economies either contracted or saw minimal growth in the last quarter. This could weigh somewhat on the UK economy in the coming months, particularly with such a gloomy picture in the eurozone.” The Retail Price Index, the wider measure of inflation, dropped slightly to 2.5% in July. That means that rail fares in England and Wales are likely to rise by 3.5% on average, and up to 5.5% in some cases, in 2015. The chancellor, though, could yet cap rises at a lower rate.... The ONS also reported that UK house prices hit a new record high in June, although the pace of growth moderated. 2014 was meant to be the year when real UK wages started growing, and interest rates rose. But it’s not working out that way. Our economics editor, Larry Elliott, writes: Even with July’s drop in inflation [to 1.6%], prices are still rising faster than earnings, which are going up at an annual rate of 0.6%. At the start of the year there was a lot of talk about how 2014 was going to be the year of the pay rise. That now looks unlikely. Living standards will carry on falling deep into the autumn even if wages do start to pick up. Some City analysts think 2014 will also be the year of the interest rate rise. That, too, is starting to look questionable given not just the weakness of CPI inflation but also the lack of any real price pressure in the pipeline. The producer prices index, a guide to the costs paid by manufacturers and the price of goods leaving factory gates, shows that the drop in fuel and raw material costs together with tight control of pay is allowing firms to cut tariff prices. An interest rate rise by the end of the year – November being the likeliest date – should not be ruled out, but it will be on the basis of what the Bank of England’s monetary policy committee thinks is going to happen to inflation rather than what is actually happening. More here: UK inflation figures - say goodbye to your pay rise Today’s inflation figures have been grasped by both sides of the political spectrum. The Treasury claims that today’s fall in the Consumer Prices Index, from 1.9% to 1.6%, is a sign that its policies are bearing fruit. A spokesperson said: “The government’s long term economic plan is working, with today marking the 7th consecutive month that inflation has been below the Bank of England’s two per cent target. “But the effects of the great recession are still being felt and so we have taken continued action to help with the cost of living, including cutting income tax, freezing fuel duty and reducing the costs of childcare. The job is not yet done so the government will go on making the realistic assessment of what needs to be done to deliver a brighter economic future” Liberal Democrat Chief Secretary to the Treasury, Danny Alexander, told Sky News: “The fact that inflation has been below the Bank of England target for seven consecutive months shows that subdued inflation is now becoming the norm as the economy recovers. “Eliminating the deficit fairly, and repairing the UK economy remains central to the role of Liberal Democrats in Government. “These encouraging inflation numbers should give businesses the confidence they need to deliver the investment required to boost productivity. Rising productivity is the only route to sustainable increases in living standards.” The opposition Labour party, meanwhile, points out that real incomes are still shrinking. Cathy Jamieson MP, Shadow Treasury Minister, says: “While this fall in the rate of inflation is welcome, the squeeze on working people continues. “The latest figures show regular pay rising by just 0.6 per cent - less than half the rate of inflation announced today. Wages after inflation have now fallen by over £1,600 a year under this government. “Labour’s economic plan will deal with the cost-of-living crisis, make Britain better off and earn our way to higher living standards for all, not just a few.” Our Money editor Patrick Collinson has hit the phones, and confirms that rail fare rises in 2014 could be lower than the 3.5% that is widely expected. As flagged up in my last post, it’s all down to George Osborne.... Over to Patrick: This morning virtually every story on rail fares is assuming that prices for ‘regulated’ fares will rise by 3.5% from next year, using the formula of July’s RPI figure plus 1%. But there is absolutely no guarantee that will be the outcome. In the autumn statement last year, the Chancellor cancelled the RPI+1% increase scheduled for January 2014, replacing it with just a straightforward RPI increase. What will happen in January 2015? We know that the RPI figure will be used - but whether it will be +1% or zero, or something else, is for now speculative. This morning, a Department for Transport spokesman said: “No decisions on fare rises for 2015 have yet been taken. We understand people’s concerns about the cost of travel and the impact this has on family budgets. That is why for 2014 we reduced average fare rises to RPI plus 0% for the first time in a decade.” The reality is that the DfT do not know precisely when a decision will be taken on the level of increases for 2015, as it is ultimately a Treasury decision. In this year’s pre-election autumn statement, the chancellor could rule out inflation-plus increases, switch to the CPI measure used for welfare benefits, or even revert to the formula used in the years immediately after rail privatisation, when fares went up by RPI minus 1%. That would be a popular move, especially with Britons heading to the polling booths in May 2015.... One point to flag up... George Osborne could offer Britain’s rail travellers a reprieve from these hefty price rises in 2015. Last autumn, the chancellor capped average regulated fare increases at RPI, rather than RPI + 1% (up to RPI +3 for some fares). Potentially, Osborne could extend this freeze for another year... We’re collecting expert reaction to today’s inflation data here: UK inflation - what the economists say Food prices fell a little between July and June, led by bread & cereals and sugar, jam, syrups, chocolate & confectionery. That’s due to the ongoing price wars between major supermarkets, as established chains try to battle Aldi and Lidl. Mark Billige, managing Partner at pricing experts Simon-Kucher & Partners, explains: Whilst lower grocery prices are good news for consumers, they will be putting the margins of supermarkets and their suppliers under enormous pressure with a knock on effect on share prices. We expect this trend to continue as the discounters continue increasing their market share.” Alasdair Cavalla, economist at the CEBR, agrees that UK interest rates are unlikely to rise this year: A long stretch of below-target inflation increases the likelihood that the Bank of England will raise interest rates in early 2015 rather than this year. Spare capacity, which is the Bank’s stated guiding factor in its decision, is remaining higher for longer than expected. Cavalla points out that price growth is weak across the global economy: The Eurozone has been falling ever closer to deflation, while the European Central Bank is facing strong Bundesbank opposition to any monetary loosening measures. US inflation data come out later today, but at just 2.1% on the latest reading and expected to be at 2.0% today, the rate is already below the long-term average. In addition, a strong pound means that the UK economy finds imported goods even cheaper. Therefore, recent signals suggest the Bank seems likely to wait until next year before raising the base rate. The Bank of England a good excuse to keep its hands off the interest rate-raising lever until the new year, says Jake Trask, corporate dealer at UKForex. With dovish comments from BoE Governor Mark Carney last week, this fall in inflation will provide the MPC with even more reason to hold out for Q1 2015 before tightening monetary policy. We may learn more tomorrow about the intended timeframe for a rate hike when the minutes of the latest MPC meeting are released.” Here’s transport correspondent Gwyn Topham on the implications of today’s inflation data for rail passengers: Rail fares will rise by an average of 3.5% in January with some fares rising by up to 5.5%, adding hundreds of pounds to the cost of season tickets. Labour and transport campaigners are stepping up their challenge to the railway system, with protests taking place at stations across the country as the extent of planned fare rises for 2015 is revealed. Campaigners have demanded action to tackle above-inflation fare increases, pointing out that ticket prices are rising nearly four times faster than wages and average fares will have risen 25% under the coalition government. Regulated train fares are pegged to July’s retail price inflation figure of 2.5% and capped at RPI+1% – although train operators may raise fares on some routes by an extra 2%. The flex rule means some fares could rise by 5.5% – and could add more than £300 to the cost of annual season tickets on the most expensive commuter routes. Cumulatively, prices will have gone up almost 25% during the current parliament, while average wages have risen by 6.9%. According to the Campaign for Better Transport commuters are spending up to a fifth of their income on season tickets. More here: Rail fares to rise by average of 3.5% in January I believe, though, that Scottish fares will rise by just 2.5% -- control of rail north of the border has been devolved to the Scottish government. Britain’s double-digit house price inflation (see last entry) is a blow to those hoping to get into the housing ladder. Campbell Robb, the chief executive of housing charity Shelter, has urged the government to do more: “Today’s house price hike is yet another blow for people across the country desperate to put down roots and create a stable home. “No matter how hard people work or save, millions are being priced out of a home of their own, caught in the ‘rent trap’ and constantly moving from one expensive property to the next. “The only solution is for politicians to roll up their sleeves and build the affordable homes we so desperately need. From a new generation of part rent part buy homes, to encouraging smaller builders back into the market, there are ways to fix this country’s housing crisis.“If we don’t see radical action soon, more and more people will be left without a hope of ever building a stable future in a home of their own.” We also have data showing that UK house price growth slowed a little at the start of the summer. The average house price rose by 10.2% in the 12 months to June, according to the ONS. That’s down from 10.4% in the year to May. It says: House price annual inflation was 10.7% in England, 3.5% in Wales, 6.0% in Scotland and 4.9% in Northern Ireland. House prices are increasing strongly across most parts of the UK, with prices in London again showing the highest growth. Average prices in the capital have surged by 19.3% over the last 12 months, and are now a staggering 35.6% higher than the pre-financial crisis peak in January 2008. But more recent data has suggested that sellers in London are now cutting prices; a sign the market may be cooling off... The inflation data is online here. There are also signs that British firms face less inflationary pressure. Producer input prices (basically, what firms pay for raw materials) dropped 1.6% month-on-month in July, and are a chunky 7.3% lower than a year ago. Output prices (what they charge for their goods) fell slightly too. The 5.7% drop in clothing prices last month came from “a wide range of men’s, women’s and children’s outerwear, for example trousers, coats and jumpers”, the ONS adds. The chances of the Bank of England raising interest rates in 2014 have fallen, flags up Jeremy Cook of currency firm World First: So, why the big drop in inflation last month? The Office for National Statistics says that the biggest single factor driving CPI down to 1.6% was clothing prices, which tumbled by 5.7% between June and July. That suggests that summer clothing sales kicked off in earnest in July, after being delayed from June. Other large downward effects came from the alcohol, financial services and food & non-alcoholic drinks. The ONS explains: Alcohol & tobacco prices, overall, fell by 0.7% between June and July this year but rose by 0.6% a year ago. The downward effect came from a range of alcohol products, principally spirits and wine. For both groups, prices fell this year but rose a year ago. But transport costs rose, by 1.3% between June and July. The pound has taken a tumble as City traders react to the larger-than-expected fall in inflation last month. It’s down 0.5%, or 0.8 of a cent, at $1.665, as the guessing game of when the Bank of England will raise interest rates takes another twist. Here’s some instant reaction to the news that the headline UK inflation rate fell by more than expected in July: The Retail Prices Index, a broader measure of inflation, has also fallen, to 2.5% in July. That means average rail fares will rise by 3.5% next year, under the government’s RPI +1% formula. But rail operators are allowed to raise some fares by as much as RPI +3%, meaning some unlucky commuters face paying 5.5% extra in 2015. Breaking: The UK consumer prices index has tumbled to 1.6% in July, a sharp fall on June’s 1.9%. That should bring some relief to households, and also takes inflation further away from the Bank of England’s target of 2% inflation. But prices are still rising almost three times faster than wages --- average earnings in the UK rose by just 0.6% in the April-June quarter, according to the latest data. Lots more detail and reaction to follow.... The pound just fell against the US dollar, down 0.3 of a cent at $1.6694. Does that mean someone is anticipating a weak inflation reading in a few minutes time?.... Nearly time for the UK inflation data for July. As flagged up earlier, economists expect the UK Consumer Prices Index to have fallen a little, to 1.8% from 1.9% in June. Britain currently has the highest inflation rate in Europe, with several members of the eurozone experiencing falling prices. European stock markets are showing small gains across the board, as hopes of easing geopolitical tensions cheer the City. The FTSE 100 has gained 0.5%, or 33 points, to 6775, despite BHP Billiton (-3.5%) dragging down the index as its demerger plans sink in. Germany’s DAX has gained 1%, on hopes that Russia and Ukraine may reach an agreement to end the long-running, deadly clashes on their borders. The French CAC is up 0.44%. The Footsie being led by housebuilder Barratt Developments - which may be benefitting from strong results from rival Persimmon this morning. Persimmon, which builds homes outside the M25, reported a 57% jump in profits for the first half of 2014. The firm said the “ongoing improvement in the UK’s economic performance” was helping the sector, and claimed there was “little sign” of fatigue, despite recent signs that mortgage lending may be cooling off. Full story here. Rumours of a pact between the Bank of England and the UK Treasury to resist raising interest rates until after next May’s general election refuse to go away. City AM reports that the Treasury committee will ask governor Mark Carney about his relationship with George Osborne, after two MPs raised concerns over the closeness of their relationship. The BoE and the Treasury have tried to rubbish talk of a secret pact. But as committee member Mark Garniere explained, this speculation could be damaging: “The Bank of England has to act independently, otherwise the whole thing becomes farcical – you get back to the worst case scenario where the chancellor is deciding rates covertly.... “The Treasury committee is very cognisant of this kind of risk.” Overnight, a former trader at Dutch bank Rabobank became the first Britain to plead guilty to charges over the Libor scandal. Paul Robson had been accused of taking part in a scheme to manipulate the “yen Libor rate” - a benchmark rate at which banks would lend to each other. The US justice department said Robson had pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and bank fraud. Leslie Caldwell, who heads the Justice Department’s criminal division, said: “The scope of the fraud was massive, but the scheme was simple. By illegally influencing the Libor rates, Robson and his co-conspirators rigged the markets to ensure that their trades made money.” Robson is the second Rabobank trader to plead guilty following probes into the alleged manipulation of interest rate benchmarks. More here: Ex-Rabobank trader second to plead guilty to Libor rigging Shares in BHP Billiton, the Anglo-Australian mining giant, have promptly dropped by 3% in early trading after it announced plans to spin off its aluminium, coal, manganese, nickel and silver assets into a new company. It’s a massive demerger -- which appears to unpick much of the deal that created the group in 2001. Jac Nasser, BHP chairman, says the deal will “provide investors with choice and unlock value in both companies.” Rail campaigners have already warned that fares are rising too fast, even before today’s inflation data is released. The Campaign for Better Transport argues that the “Retail Prices Index +1%” formula (or RPI + 3% for some fares) needs to change, as some commuters could pay an extra £300 each next year. Spokesman Martin Abrams isn’t impressed that some fares could rise by around 5.6% (depending on today’s data, of course!): “With people’s wages stagnating, and in some cases falling, the expense of taking the train to work has become a huge part of living costs. If the government doesn’t put an end to above-inflation fare increases quickly, ordinary commuters will be priced off the train and could be forced into agonising decisions such as moving house or quitting their jobs” More here: Labour and transport campaigners step up rail fares fight as prices rise again Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, business and the eurozone. Inflation is high on the agenda, with new surveys showing the cost of living in Britain and America due out today. The UK’s Consumer Prices Index index is expected to fall a little, after spiking unexpectedly last month. Economists predict CPI will dip to 1.8% in July, from 1.9%, at 9.30am. That would mean prices were running three times faster than average wages (which rose just 0.6% in the three months to June). Cue plenty more justifiable concern that the UK recovery hasn’t reached workers’ pockets. Today’s inflation data is particularly important for UK commuters, as the wider Retail Prices Index will be used to calculate next year’s rail fare increases. RPI is expected to be unchanged at 2.6%. Rail operators are allowed to increase fares by an average of RPI + 1%. But under a “flex” rule, train companies can raise some fares by another 2% above the average, as long as they make cuts elsewhere. So some passengers could face an inflation-busting 5.6% increase, even if the service isn’t that much better.... America’s July inflation data is due at 1.30pm BST (8.30am New York), and is also expected to show a slight drop. That could reduce the pressure on the US Federal Reserve to start raising interest rates, as it comes to the end of its bond-buying stimulus programme. CMC Market’s Michael Hewson explains: In the afternoon session we also get the latest US CPI inflation numbers and they are expected to slip slightly from the 2.1% in June to 2% in July. A similarly weak number would undermine the recent rise in the US dollar as markets bet that rates are likely to remain lower for longer. In the corporate world, mining giant BHP Billiton has just announced plans to spin off many of its operations into a new “Global Metals and Mining Company”. More on that shortly. Stock markets are expected to continue where they stopped yesterday, rising on hopes that the Ukraine crisis is easing. Last night, the US Nasdaq index hit its highest closing level in 14 years (a peak that was swiftly followed by the dot-com crash....). And in the City, building firm Persimmon has reported that demand in the housing market remains strong after a leap in profits. I’ll be tracking the main developments through the day.
