fields.trailText: Britain’s consumer prices index fell sharply last month, but rail campaigners won’t be happy that fares will rise by up to 5.5%

webTitle: FTSE hits three week high with AstraZeneca boosted as US closes Brilinta probe

fields.standfirst: Leading shares move higher again as investors brush aside geopolitical worries
fields.body:
AstraZeneca shares have fallen sharply since the pharmaceuticals company rebuffed a $118bn offer from US group Pfizer in May.

But ahead of a possible return by Pfizer later this month - in the unlikely event of being invited by AstraZeneca to bid again - there was good news for the UK company as US regulators closed a probe into its new heart drug Brilinta. The US Department of Justice said in October it would investigate a major clinical trial used to win marketing approval for the treatment, but on Tuesday it said no further action was planned. Brilinta was one of the drugs whose prospects AstraZeneca highlighted in its defence against the Pfizer bid. Chief executive Pascal Soriot said:

We have always had absolute confidence in the integrity of the ....trial. As one of AstraZeneca's growth platforms, we are committed to delivering the full potential of this important medicine.

AstraZeneca added 37p to 4238.5p.

Overall markets moved higher again on hopes of easing geopolitical tensions, and amid inflation figures from both sides of the Atlantic which suggested there was unlikely to be any rise in UK or US interest rates in the near future. But stronger than expected US housing starts muddied the picture a little.

Wednesday's Bank of England minutes should provide further clues as to the central bank's thinking, while later in the week come speeches from Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen and ECB boss Mario Draghi at latest Jackson Hole meeting in Wyoming.

Ahead of all that, the FTSE 100 finished up 38.06 points at 6779.31 - a three week high - while German and French markets also gained ground. On Wall Street the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 60 points by the time London closed.

Barratt Developments was 10.4p better at 368.6p after positive results from rival housebuilder Persimmon, up 15p at £13.50.

These further signs of an improvement in the UK housing market helped lift Kingfisher, owner of the B&Q DIY chain, by 11.2p to 310.6p.

Elsewhere Imperial Tobacco added 59p to £25.85 after it said it expected modest growth in full year earnings following an improvement in the European market. But it saw a deterioration in Russian sales as well as the impact of turbulence in the Middle East, notably in Iraq of course.

But CRH lost 28p to £14.28 despite the Irish building supplies company returned to profit in the first six months.

Mining group BHP Billiton fell 102p to £19.65 as it said it would spin off some $14bn worth of assets - including aluminium, manganese and some nickel and coal - into an as yet unnamed company, effectively undoing much of the 2001 merger between BHP and Billiton.

The fall reflected disappointment with investors receiving shares in the new company listed in Australia and South Africa, the lack of a buyback and an underwhelming 8% rise in second half profits.

Among the mid-caps, Ophir Energy jumped 15.2p to 229.6p on talk of possible US bid interest at 350p a share.

There was also takeover speculation surrounding building materials suppler SIG, up 5.3p at 183p.

Energy services company Wood Group rose 37p to 788.5p despite first half earnings which were virtually flat at $243.9m. However the company said it expected a rise for the full year helped by progress in its production services division, PSN. Its shale projects fall mainly within PSN, which accounts for around 60% of total revenue.

Mears, the social housing and care specialist, slipped 8.5p to 484.75p even though half year profits grew 11% to £18.7m. Contracts worth £200m were won during the period, but its order book dipped from £3.8bn to £3.7bn after changes in housing finance and welfare reforms led to a short term delay in new bidding opportunities. But analysts were positive, with Peel Hunt saying:

A strong first half operational performance led to a 17% increase in earnings per share. Although order intake has been quieter, margin momentum remains positive (up 40 basis points). Cash conversion remains strong, with net cash of £2.7m. The outlook remains positive and we confidently retain our estimates. The shares, trading on 15.1 times December 2014 estimated earnings per share, provide scope for re-rating as well as the potential for positive earnings surprise. Buy.

Liberum said:

Reassuringly robust first half results support our ongoing positive stance. We continue to expect double digit earnings per share growth, a strong balance sheet and good free cash flow. The bears will focus on the lack of order book growth (and the associated revenue downgrade). However, this should be taken in the context of better than expected progress at [subsidiary] Morrison and the opportunity for acquisition related upgrades. We expect orders to accelerate in 2015 and in the meantime expect Mears to continue to meet our 10% earnings per share compound annual growth rate forecasts. Buy, £5.60 target price.

Finally Dan Wagner - whose Dialog group soared and slumped during the dotcom boom before being taken private - has seen one of his new businesses get off to a good start to public life. Attraqt, which provides ecommerce software to online retailers such as Tesco Clothing, TK Maxx, Boohoo and Superdry, rose from its 50p listing price to close at 53.5p.

webTitle: Central banks need exit strategy from post-crisis policies

fields.bodyText: September 16 2008 was the day central banks stopped being boring. The day Lehman Brothers went down was the cut-off point between conventional monetary policy – moving official interest rates in baby steps to keep inflation low – and unconventional monetary policy. Interest rates came down in big leaps to barely above zero. Central banks bought long-term government bonds and risky assets, providing money in return in the process known as quantitative easing. Forward guidance embedded the idea that borrowing would remain cheap for a long time. Schemes, such as the Bank of England's Funding for Lending, were introduced to get the commercial banks lending once more. The rule book was torn up. Almost six years on, the post-Lehman regime remains in place. The perceived wisdom among central banks is that unconventional monetary policy prevented a deep recession turning into a second Great Depression and that unwinding the emergency measures too quickly would threaten what is still a tentative global recovery. A new working paper by two International Monetary Fund economists does not challenge the idea that things could have turned really nasty had it not been for the slashing of interest rates, QE and all the other wheezes dreamed up by central banks. Even so, the paper by Frederic Lambert and Kenichi Ueda (The effects of unconventional monetary policies on bank soundness) makes uncomfortable reading. It argues that the policies pursued by central banks since 2008 have not made commercial banks more profitable. But they have made banks riskier and more likely to delay repairs to their balance sheets. "Unconventional monetary policy is often assumed to benefit banks. However, we find little supporting evidence. Rather, we find some evidence for heightened medium-term risks", Lambert and Ueda say. The implications are clear. One of the side effects of unconventional monetary policy is that banks are encouraged by low interest rates to seek out higher yielding – and riskier – investments, while QE gives them more scope to do so. The risks increase the longer the unconventional policies remain in place. Lambert and Ueda do not speak for the IMF, which has been a keen supporter of unconventional policies. Even so, this is an important paper. It suggests that the Fund and the world's leading central banks need an exit strategy from the policies of the past six years. Otherwise, they could be storing up big problems for the future.

webTitle: Hornby's second world war aircraft model a silver lining for struggling toymaker

fields.bodyText: A detailed model of a second world war attack plane has proved a hit for struggling toymaker Hornby, which has sold 8,000 units since launching the model. The Hawker Typhoon, which costs £99.99 and has 509 parts, is a copy of the second world war aircraft that knocked out German radar before D-day, playing an important role in the allied air attack during the Battle of the Bulge. It is mostly being bought by adults who make models for a hobby, according to the company. Sam Townshend, its designer, has said that building and painting the model in accurate colours could take up to a year. The success of the Typhoon is a boost for Hornby, which also makes Scalextric cars and Humbrol paints but has been hit by a multitude of problems, from unreliable Chinese suppliers to a disastrous Olympics that left the company sitting on mountains of unsold London 2012-themed goods. The company reported a £4.5m loss in June after annual revenues dropped 10% to £52m. In an attempt to modernise its operations, it is leaving its Margate warehouse for an industrial estate at Hersden, 11 miles away. In a trading update, the company said it was confident of "growing profitability". • This article was amended on 19 August. The original described the Hawker Typhoon as a jet aircraft. This has been corrected.

webTitle: Waitrose launches bid for 'transumers' in first railway station outlet

fields.standfirst: Attracting 'travelling consumers' is part of supermarket's new strategy as Little Waitrose opens at King's Cross in London
fields.body:
Waitrose has opened its first outlet at a railway station in an effort to attract "transumers" – or travelling consumers.

The 2,500 sq ft (230 sq metres) Little Waitrose store at King's Cross, central London, is the grocer's smallest outlet to date, crammed into a corner site at the heart of the station. Yet it still has an on-site bakery as well as snacks, ready meals, everyday basics and fresh fruit and vegetables.

The supermarket is also launching small-format stores in southern counties including Hampshire, Oxfordshire and Bedfordshire after opening most of its new directly operated sites in central London.

Jackie Wharton, director of convenience for Waitrose, said the "transumer" was a fast-growing market that provided an opportunity for a loyal following.

While the retailer is likely to look at other station concourse shops if the King's Cross outlet proves successful, Wharton said Waitrose was looking at opening stores near stations and other travel hubs rather than in traditional town centres, where people passing by may be more focused on buying fashion or meeting friends for lunch than picking up groceries.

"What is successful is becoming part of customers' daily pattern, so that they are going past the door in the morning and evening either by their homes or work. Today we want to do things when we want and how we want and that theme has come to food retailing. The landscape is changing hugely," she said.

As part of its attempt to target commuters, Waitrose is also putting lockers at tube stations and at Gatwick airport for customers to pick up goods ordered online.

Waitrose plans to open 10 convenience outlets by the end of January next year, including one close to Manchester Piccadilly station.

About 70% of the group's 45 Little Waitrose stores are in the south-east of England, with most of those further north run by the supermarket's franchise partner Welcome Break, which operates motorway service station outlets.

Waitrose has been overtaken as Britain's sixth-largest supermarket by Aldi, the German discounter. Waitrose, which is part of the staff-owned John Lewis Partnership, admitted this month that profits would fall this year as it invested in matching the price cuts of its bigger rivals on key items as well as opening stores and expanding or improving others.

webTitle: Reforms are needed to tackle house price volatility

fields.standfirst: Higher buy-to-let taxes and the introduction of a deposit after an agreement to buy would take the heat out of the market
fields.body:
House prices began to cool in May according to official figures. The data from the Office for National Statistics confirms what we knew, or at least surmised from reports by estate agents and property experts, which is that tighter lending rules introduced in April slowed galloping property inflation. In the summer, the threat of higher interest rates spooked sellers, who turned a trickle of estate agency mandates earlier in the year into a bubbling torrent.

It goes to show that while politicians have fixated on the shortage of housebuilding as the main reason for rising prices, the game played by property investors, especially as they weigh up interest rate expectations, has also been a major factor.

Prices are a result of supply and demand and low interest rates over the past four years have spurred demand. At the same time, the prospect of rising prices has deterred sellers from increasing supply.

We can see that May was a turning point. In the months following, transactions climbed and price inflation slowed. In August, which saw a 20% rise in sellers according to one report, there was a rush to offload property and asking prices actually fell.

There is little under the current tax and buying regulations the government or the Bank of England, which sets interest rates, can do to manage this volatility. It is what it is, a market driven by panicking amateur investors herded by a real estate industry that appears to enjoy the property price rollercoaster ride.

If policymakers really wanted to take the heat out of the market, they could tax it more heavily, and by that I mean buy-to-let properties that accrue gains while writing off losses and maintenance costs. Developers should also pay a higher charge for piggybacking on the provision by local taxpayers of good roads, schools and other attractive amenities.

The dance between buyers and sellers, which can last for months only to end in rejection, could also be reformed easily with the introduction of a 10% deposit following an agreement to buy. It is a method used in the US to prevent the constant speculation and downright piracy that infects what should be a serious and long-term commitment. Deposits are placed in an independent escrow account and can only be retrieved should the buyer be deceived and the property not be all it seems.

No system is ideal, but if we want to stop worrying about house price crashes every few years, we need higher land and property tax charges and to tie buyers to their handshake agreement with a deposit.

webTitle: Imperial Tobacco hit by weak sales in Russia and Middle East unrest

fields.bodyText: Imperial Tobacco, the world's fourth-largest cigarette company, has been hit by weaker sales in Russia and unrest in the Middle East. The maker of Davidoff and Gauloises cigarettes blamed tough conditions in a number of its key markets, highlighting "a significant deterioration in the Russian market and the impact of the turbulent situation in the Middle East". Russians are among the heaviest smokers in the world – with around 400,000 people dying of smoking-related diseases each year according to official figures – but the government has been clamping down on the habit. A ban on smoking in bars and restaurants came into force in June, as well as restrictions on selling cigarettes on street kiosks. At the same time, Imperial has been hit by unrest in the Middle East, as suppliers struggle to deliver cigarettes in Iraq and Syria. Imperial said its markets are shrinking by around 4% a year, although some of its best-selling brands continue to grow. Total sales continue to decline in Europe, as smoking bans and graphic health warnings contribute to a decline in the number of smokers, but Imperial said it had seen "a modest deceleration in the rate of market decline in parts of Europe". Imperial Tobacco reported a 1% fall in revenue to £4.8bn for the nine months to the end of June, as it was hit by adverse swings in foreign exchange. The company is only the latest FTSE 100 member with a global business to feel the strong pound weighing on profits – rival British American Tobacco reported last month that profits were down 9% on currency fluctuations. In a trading statement, Imperial also promised to update shareholders on the $7.1bn (£4.3bn) deal it struck last month to buy American cigarette brands, including Winston, Maverick and blu e-cigarettes, from two US tobacco companies, Lorillard and Reynolds, who are merging. The deal, which is expected to be complete in 2015, will catapult Bristol-based Imperial into the No 3 spot in the US market. Imperial launched its first e-cigarette in Britain this year – a device named Puritane that is made by its subsidiary Fontem Ventures and sold in pharmacists. The arrival of big tobacco companies into the e-cigarette market has alarmed health campaigners who fear the devices "renormalise" smoking rather than help people quit. More than 100 public health experts recently urged the World Health Organisation to bring e-cigarettes under the same tight controls as tobacco products, with bans on advertising and promotion.

webTitle: Wood Group shares jump 5% on US shale hopes

fields.standfirst: Company reports flat earning for first half but expects increase for full year
fields.body:
US shale projects are boosting business at energy services company Wood Group, helping to offset a fall in its engineering division.

First half earnings were virtually flat at $243.9m, but the company said it expected a rise for the full year helped by progress in its production services division, PSN. Its shale projects fall mainly within PSN, which accounts for around 60% of total revenue. In the first half PSN earnings rose by 47% but the engineering business - which designs and maintains oil and gas facilities and pipelines - dropped by 9%.

The positive outlook has seen Wood's shares jump 35p or nearly 5% to 786.5p. Credit Suisse issued an outperform rating, saying:

Wood Group's first half 2014 results and the outlook for 2014 reflect the importance of its exposure to US shale within (mainly) the PSN business. This shale exposure is a key factor that we expect will continue to differentiate Wood Group from sector peers in Europe, and yet still seems to be less well appreciated by the investment community than it should be.
There is sufficient balance sheet capacity for Wood to pursue more value-enhancing deals in the US shale regions, as well as to complete the Agility Projects deal in the third quarter. After results we lower our 2014/15 earnings per share forecasts by 1%/3% for weaker Turbine Activities, but target price remains at 890p a share.

Meanwhile Investec said:

Engineering margins are weaker than expected, but EBITA should be supported by recent acquisitions. Despite weak sector sentiment, the upside to our unchanged target price [of 825p] is starting to look more compelling.

webTitle: UK inflation figures - say goodbye to your pay rise

fields.bodyText: The City was surprised by the fall in the annual inflation rate to 1.6%. It shouldn't have been since the explanation was simple: the summer sales came late this year. Clothing and footwear retailers cut their prices by 5.7% in July, a heftier discount than the 3.2% in July 2013. By contrast, Primark, Topshop, Kurt Geiger and all the other big names of the high street cut their prices by less this June than they did in the same month of 2013. As a result, inflation was a bit higher than might have been expected in June but a bit lower in July. The annual increase in the cost of living as measured by the Consumer Prices Index (CPI) has settled in a narrow range just below the government's 2% target; in the past seven months it has never been higher than 1.9% and never lower than 1.6%. Even with July's drop in inflation, prices are still rising faster than earnings, which are going up at an annual rate of 0.6%. At the start of the year there was a lot of talk about how 2014 was going to be the year of the pay rise. That now looks unlikely. Living standards will carry on falling deep into the autumn even if wages do start to pick up. Some City analysts think 2014 will also be the year of the interest rate rise. That, too, is starting to look questionable given not just the weakness of CPI inflation but also the lack of any real price pressure in the pipeline. The producer prices index, a guide to the costs paid by manufacturers and the price of goods leaving factory gates, shows that the drop in fuel and raw material costs together with tight control of pay is allowing firms to cut tariff prices. An interest rate rise by the end of the year – November being the likeliest date – should not be ruled out, but it will be on the basis of what the Bank of England's monetary policy committee thinks is going to happen to inflation rather than what is actually happening. Inflation is below target; earnings are going up by just 0.6% on average; oil prices are falling; a strong pound is reducing the cost of imports. Nothing there to get the alarm bells ringing. The sting in the tail from the inflation figures is that rail travellers could see fares rise by an average of 3.5% in the New Year. That's because the government's formula, suspended by George Osborne for 2014, is for fares to go up by one percentage point more than inflation as measured by the July Retail Prices Index, which stood at 2.5%. Note how the government uses the RPI -– no longer thought reliable enough to be considered an official statistic by the ONS – as the yardstick for rail fares but the lower CPI to uprate benefits and pensions. The party that pledges to put an end to this scam will pick up plenty of votes in commuterland.

webTitle: UK inflation - what the economists say

fields.standfirst: The annual rate of UK inflation fell more than expected in July to 1.6% from 1.9% in June. Here's what the economists say
fields.body:
The annual rate of UK inflation fell more than expected in July to 1.6% from 1.9% in June, after heavy discounting among clothing retailers. The City had forecast a smaller drop to 1.8%. It was the seventh month in a row that inflation was below the Bank of England's 2% target, and appeared to ease the immediate dilemma facing policymakers at Threadneedle Street over the appropriate timing of a first rise in interest rates. Rates have been on hold at 0.5% since March 2009.

James Knightley at ING

On the face of it this supports an on-hold stance from the Bank of England. The combination of sterling strength (making imported goods cheaper), along with weak wage growth and lower energy prices, which are limiting business cost growth, means inflation looks set to remain contained for now. This further eases the pressure on the Bank of England to consider near-term interest rate rises and pushes the balance more in favour of a delay to rate hikes versus our current November official view for the first policy tightening move.

David Kern at the British Chambers of Commerce

The welcome fall in inflation confirms that the increase in June was temporary and doesn't signal a new upward trend. While wage increases remain very low and the pound is still relatively strong, we expect inflation to remain below the 2% target for the foreseeable future.

Although the recovery remains on track, it is still fragile and now is not the time to put it at risk with premature interest rate rises. We must nurture the business confidence we are seeing at present by giving businesses the security of working in a low interest rate environment.

Samuel Tombs at Capital Economics

July's fall in UK CPI inflation puts it back on a downward trend which we still think could see it ease to as low as 1% by the end of the year. The decline in CPI inflation from 1.9% in June to 1.6% was in line with our below-consensus forecast.

While low inflation may not be sufficient to prevent the Bank of England's monetary policy committee from moving to "normalise" interest rates soon, we believe that a general environment of benign inflationary pressure will give the committee scope to raise them at an even more gradual pace than currently anticipated by the markets.

Ian Stewart at Deloitte

Today's figures show an unexpectedly marked dip in inflation, coupled with weak pay numbers. This eases the pressure on the Bank of England for early interest rate hikes.

Jeremy Cook at World First

For the majority of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, this figure will come as a bit of a relief. No policymaker would want to be caught between the rock and the hard place of a decision between heading off an inflation number running higher and a wage picture that is seeing pay fall in both real and nominal terms.

The unemployment rate can easily come lower before inflation pressure pick up and with that inflation outlook we can easily see the Bank of England holding off on a normalisation of monetary policy into the first quarter of next year.

webTitle: UK inflation fall to 1.6% lessens likelihood of interest rate rise

fields.bodyText: The UK's annual inflation rate fell more sharply than expected in July, dimming the prospects of an interest rate rise in 2014. The consumer prices index fell to 1.6% from 1.9% in June, marking the seventh month in a row that annual inflation has registered below the Bank of England's 2% target, according to Office for National Statistics data. Economists had expected a smaller fall to 1.8%. The larger-than-expected drop was driven mainly by greater summer price discounting among clothing retailers than is usual at this time of year. Clothing and footwear prices fell by 5.7% between June and July, compared with a smaller fall of 3.2% during the same period last year. Prices were slashed on a wide range of items, including trousers, coats and jumpers. Alcohol prices, the cost of some financial services including bank overdraft charges, and food also contributed to the fall. A Treasury spokesman gave credit for the fall in inflation to the government. "The government's long-term economic plan is working, with today marking the seventh consecutive month that inflation has been below the Bank of England's two per cent target. "But the effects of the great recession are still being felt and so we have taken continued action to help with the cost of living, including cutting income tax, freezing fuel duty and reducing the costs of childcare. The job is not yet done so the government will go on making the realistic assessment of what needs to be done to deliver a brighter economic future." The news was not all good for consumers, who face average rail fare rises of 3.5% in 2015. The July inflation rate on the retail prices index (RPI) measure is used to calculate rail fare rises, and dropped to 2.5% last month from 2.6% in June. Increases are traditionally capped at RPI+1% – although train operators may raise fares on some routes by an extra 2%. That means some rail fares could increase by up to 5.5%. Mark Carney, the Bank of England governor, has given mixed messages in recent weeks on the likely timing of a first increase in interest rates, which have left been on hold at 0.5% since March 2009. Economists said lack of inflationary pressure in the UK, coupled with weak wage growth, made a rate hike in 2014 less likely. James Knightley, economist at ING, said: "On the face of it this supports an on-hold stance from the Bank of England. The combination of sterling strength (making imported goods cheaper), along with weak wage growth and lower energy prices, which are limiting business cost growth, means inflation looks set to remain contained for now. "This further eases the pressure on the Bank of England to consider near-term interest rate rises and pushes the balance more in favour of a delay to rate hikes versus our current November official view for the first policy tightening move." Despite below target inflation, household budgets remain under pressure because wage growth has lagged behind the inflation rate for the vast majority over the past six years. Pay growth including bonuses fell by 0.2% between April and June compared with a year earlier. Stripping out bonuses, pay was 0.6% – less than a third of June's 1.9% inflation rate. Cathy Jamieson, Labour's shadow Treasury minister, said: "While this fall in the rate of inflation is welcome, the squeeze on working people continues." The pound fell against the dollar and the euro after the July data was published, as investors interpreted it as a sign that rates would stay on hold into 2015. The pound fell to $1.6634, its lowest in more than eight months, while the euro rose 0.4% to 80.25p.

webTitle: FTSE 100 continues rise but BHP drops on demerger news

fields.standfirst: Mining group to split off assets but profits and lack of buyback disappoint investors
fields.body:
Markets are continuing this week's rally, on hopes of easing geopolitical tensions, but mining group BHP Billiton's plans to do the splits seems to have received the thumbs down from the City.

BHP will spin off some $14bn worth of assets - including aluminium, manganese and some nickel and coal - into an as yet unnamed company, effectively undoing much of the 2001 merger between BHP and Billiton.

But with investors receiving shares in the new company listed in Australia and South Africa, as well as disappointment over the lack of a buyback and a disappointing 8% rise in second half profits, BHP is down 81.5p at 1985.5p. This makes it the biggest faller in the leading index. Numis said:

Full-year progressive base dividend increased by 4% to 121c a share by paying final dividend of 62c a share. This is good although likely to be a disappointment for some shareholders who were hoping for a special dividend or a share buy-back. BHP has previously said it would look to increase shareholder returns once net debt falls to $25bn.
So, maybe it's a bit too early for a bumper payout, and we think the SpinCo has definitely clouded the issue of shareholder returns as BHP will view the SpinCo itself as a "return". Although we think the demerger strategy looks sound and will likely benefit shareholders, it's nowhere near as tangible as a share buy-back. Stock likely to fall temporally on this disappointment as shareholders mull the fact that you rarely get what you wish for...

Despite this, the FTSE 100 is up 29.14 points at 6770.39, helped by optimism that the global problems in Ukraine, Iraq and Gaza could be easing slightly.

Barratt Developments is the biggest riser in the leading index, up 13.2p at 371.4p after positive results from rival Persimmon, up 17p at £13.52.

Elsewhere Imperial Tobacco has added 52p to £25.78 after it said it expected modest growth in full year earnings following an improvement in the European market. But it saw a deterioration in Russian sales as well as the impact of turbulence in the Middle East, notably in Iraq of course.

It added that its acquisition of assets from US groups Lorillard and Reynolds, which are merging, was on track to be completed in 2015. The deal would make it the biggest e-cigarette maker in the US.

But CRH has lost 15p to £14.41 despite the Irish building supplies company returned to profit in the first six months.

webTitle: BHP Billiton profits soar 23% to $US15bn as metals spin-off goes ahead

fields.standfirst: Mining giant says demerger will help the group focus on its core iron ore, copper and oil operations
fields.body:
BHP Billiton will spin off its metals businesses into a separate unit to be listed in Australia as the mining conglomerate seeks to focus on its core iron ore, coal and oil business.

The announcement came as BHP lifted its full-year profit 23% to $US13.8bn ($A15bn) on Tuesday, buoyed by a 15th straight year of record iron ore production.

Chief executive Andrew Mackenzie said BHP had delivered on its commitments in the past 12 months.

“Our operational performance continued to improve, enabling us to exceed production guidance for a number of our core commodities including iron ore, metallurgical coal and petroleum liquids,” he said.

BHP will pay a final dividend of 62 US cents per share, up from 59 US cents per share one year earlier.

Despite a strong boost ahead of the announcements in the Australian listing, BHP shares fell 3.6% when trading opened in London as investors digested the news.

In a well-trailed move, Australia’s biggest company also announced on Tuesday that it will create an independent metals and mining company from its aluminium, metallurgical coal, manganese, nickel and silver assets.

It said the planned demerger would unlock shareholder value by rationalising the group’s structure.

The simplified company would then focus on its huge iron ore, copper, coal, oil and potash assets where it would be able to reduce costs and improve productivity.

The spin-off company will be based in Perth and led by current BHP board member David Crawford as chairman and current BHP finance chief Graham Kerr as chief executive.

Announcing the changes, group chairman Jac Nasser, said: “For over a century, BHP Billiton has progressively reshaped its business to maintain its industry leadership. We believe the proposed demerger, if implemented, will accelerate the simplification of the group’s portfolio, provide investors with choice and unlock value in both companies.

“Our shareholders will have the opportunity to vote on this proposal once the necessary approvals are in place.”

The so-called “NewCo” would have assets including BHP’s aluminium and manganese businesses, Cerro Matoso Nickel, Energy Coal South Africa, Illawarra Metallurgical Coal and Cannington Silver-Lead-Zinc mines.

BHP shareholders would be entitled to 100% of the shares in NewCo on a pro-rata basis and would be listed on the Australian Securities Exchange with a secondary listing on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange.

webTitle: Persimmon reports 57% profit rise amid housebuilding recovery

fields.standfirst: Building profits soar as Persimmon unveils plans to take on new staff and develop 100 sites amid increasing demand
fields.body:
One of the country's largest homebuilders, Persimmon, has reported a 57% increase in profits, as the recovery in the housing market takes root across the UK.

Persimmon, which builds houses across the country outside the M25, reported improved confidence across the regions, against the backdrop of "ongoing improvement in the UK's economic performance".

Stronger economic conditions helped push up the average selling price to £186,970, a 4.3% increase on last year. The builder, whose brands include Charles Church and Westbury Partnerships, sold 6,408 completed homes in the first half of 2014, a 28% increase on the same period last year. Pre-tax profits rose to £213m, up from £135m the previous year.

Persimmon's robust performance comes after its rival Bovis reported a first-half profits rise of 166%, boosted by a 20% increase in average sales prices to £239,500 during the same period.

Although builders' profits are soaring, estate agents have warned that the housing market has started to cool, following comments in June from the Bank of England governor, Mark Carney, that interest rates could rise. Lenders are also tightening conditions for mortgage loans in an attempt to curb inflationary pressures in the housing market.

Persimmon, which does not build in London, the focus of anxiety about a housing bubble, has not seen demand slacken, with reservations to buy houses up 9% on last year since 1 July. "As we have entered the traditionally slower summer trading weeks, we have been encouraged by our private sale reservation rate," said the Persimmon chief executive, Jeff Fairburn. Forward sales – measured to the start of this week – are up 22% on last year.

As demand remains strong, the York-based builder also announced plans to step-up building work and take on new staff, as it outlined plans to develop 100 new sites during the second half of the year.

The strong performance is a bonus for shareholders of the FTSE 100 company. Persimmon reported a 61% increase in earnings per share to 54.8p, while its share price rose 1.1% in early trading to £13.52.

Richard Hunter at Hargreaves Lansdown Stockbrokers said Persimmon was not only taking advantage of the benign sector backdrop, where demand continues to exceed supply, but was also investing to capitalise on further growth.

"Inevitably, some concerns will continue to be expressed around the UK housing market in general and whether the current price rises are sustainable, whilst the recent hike in Persimmon's share price may raise some valuation concerns." He added: "With the sector currently showing little signs of fatigue, prospects for Persimmon remain bright."
